oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unveiling sign for "Sergeant York Avenue"
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Traffic signs & signals; Motion picture premieres; Motion picture theaters; Theaters; Spectators; People; Governors
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Cooper, Prentice, 1894-1969; Nashville (Tenn.); Knickerbocker Theatre (Nashville, Tenn.); Storer, Walter Henry, 1898-1974
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alvin C. York, his wife Gracie, York familiy members, Gov. Prentice Cooper, and spectators look on as a sign designating 6th Avenue as "Sergeant York Avenue" is unveiled. The scene takes place in front of the Knickerbocker Theatre during the premiere of the movie "Sergeant York."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Storer, Walter Henry, 1898-1974
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Dr. Walter H. Storer Photograph Collection, ca. 1930-1955
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Warner Brothers producer Jesse Lasky had sought to secure movie rights to the York story since 1919. York finally relented around 1940 when Lasky argued that Americans needed inspiration in light of the war in Europe. The film became the highest-grossing movie of 1941 and was nominated for eleven Oscars.
